title-group.article-title: A numerical study on nonlinear vibration of an inclined cable coupled with the deck in cable-stayed bridges

article-meta.aff: 1State Key Laboratory of Structural Analysis for Industrial Equipment, Dalian University of Technology, China
2School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering, University of New South Wales, Australia

author-notes.corresp: Zhan Kang, State Key Laboratory of Structural Analysis for Industrial Equipment, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian 116024, China Email: zhankang@dlut.edu.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The mechanism and the characteristics of the cable-deck coupled nonlinear vibration in a cable-stayed bridge are studied using numerical methods. A simple three-degrees-of-freedom (d.f.) model, with one independent d.f. for modeling the bridge deck movement, is proposed for describing the nonlinear interactions between the in-plane/out-of-plane vibration of the cable and the oscillation of the bridge deck. The governing equations are discretized with the Galerkin method and then solved with a numerical time integration algorithm. It is pointed out that the periodic variation of cable tension caused by vibration of a bridge deck will lead to the parametric resonance of the stay cable under certain tuning conditions. Numerical results also confirm that energy transfer between different vibration modes and beating phenomenon of the cable-deck vibration may be exhibited in the case of parametric resonance.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Since the first modern cable-stayed bridge, Stroemsund Bridge, was built in Sweden in 1956, cable-stayed bridges have gained increasing popularity because of their outstanding performance, relatively low construction cost and unique esthetic appearance. In particular, along with the rapid development of construction technologies in the last two decades, cable-stayed bridges have found wide applications throughout the world.

However, as the main load-bearing parts of a cable-stayed bridge, the stay cables are prone to large amplitude vibrations induced by various sources. In particular, the stay cables possess a high possibility of parametric resonance under the deck excitations. Therefore, the issue of the cable vibration has attracted intensive attention.

Classical cable dynamics studies can be traced back to the work of Irvine (1981), in which the linear vibration of cables with small sag was first systematically investigated. Ever since then, nonlinear vibration behaviors of suspended cables have been intensively studied. For instance, Lilien and Pinto da Costa (1994) found that very large amplitude vibration can be induced by low-frequency mechanical tension oscillations of the stay cables in large span bridges. A global/local mode approach, which can analyze the coupled vibration of cables and bridges, was introduced by Warnitchai et al. (1995). Pinto da Costa et al. (1996) studied the nonlinear cable vibration by the analytical method and numerical method. Srinil et al. (2003) considered the axial deformation effect of the cables and obtained the mid-span response. Berlioz and Lamarque (2005) studied the influences of the initial tension and inclination on the cable vibration. Nonlinear vibration behaviors of cables have also been considered by many other authors, see for example the review paper of Rega (2004) and references therein.

A number of studies have been conducted on the nonlinear dynamics of cables subject to vertical or horizontal support excitations, with the purpose of exploring the cable/deck coupling effects. Macdonald et al. (2010) showed that deck excitations around the lower-order of natural frequencies may induce large cable vibrations. Gattulli and his coworkers (Gattulli et al., 2002, 2005; Gattulli and Lepidi, 2003) developed a cable-stayed beam model and found that vibration energy can transfer from low frequencies to high frequencies through the parametric resonance. The numerical results were also confirmed by experimental studies. Gattulli and Lepidi (2007) also studied the coupled cable-deck vibration and the influence of strong mode localization on the structural response. Their study shows that a veering phenomenon may occur under particular parameter combinations that enable internal resonance between local and global modes. These predictions were verified by a refined finite element analysis of a real-world bridge. Georgakis and Taylor (2005) conducted finite element analysis of a cable subjected to harmonic excitations and examined the effects of changes in initial cable conditions. A recent paper by Caetano et al. (2008) presents a thorough investigation on several possible mechanisms of cable vibration exhibited by the International Guadiana Bridge. On-site measurements and finite element analysis suggest that the internal resonance of the cable-deck system may be a major cause of the large-amplitude cable motions. Fujino et al. (1993) presented a three-degrees-of-freedom (d.f.) nonlinear model of a cable-stayed-beam and provided analytical steady-state solutions of the autoparametric resonance between the out-of-plane cable vibration and the beam vibration. Using this model, Warnitchai et al. (1993) also studied active tendon control of cable-stayed bridge vibrations.

The nonlinear coupling between the in-plane and out-of-plane vibration has also been studied by a number of researchers. Benedettini et al. (1986) investigated the coupled in-plane and out-of-plane vibration problems of the cable with parabola curve and showed that energy transferred between these two vibration modes in the form of ‘beat’. Rao and Iyengar (1991) and Srinil et al. (2007) found that the nonlinear quadratic terms of the equation have significant effects on the cable vibration when the ratio of frequency of in-plane vibration to out-of-plane oscillation is approximately 2:1. Other theoretical and experimental studies also showed that support vibration will lead to in-plane or out-of-plane parametric resonance (see e.g. Lee and Perkins, 1995; Perkins, 1992). However, the parametric resonance model that accounts for both nonlinear coupling of an inclined stay cable and the bridge deck and the interactions between in-plane/out-of-plane vibration modes have rarely been studied in the literature.

This paper aims to investigate the coupled nonlinear vibration behaviors of the cable/deck system by numerical analysis of a proposed three-d.f. model. As compared with some existing studies considering interactions of different cable-dominant vibration modes, in which the motion of the bridge deck was specified as a harmonic vibration, the present paper not only takes into account the coupling effect of in-plane and out-of-plane vibration of the cable, but also treats the vibration of the bridge deck as an independent d.f. The coupling nonlinear equations are then derived and discretized with the Galerkin method. The transient responses of the cable under various initial conditions and frequency ratios are predicted by using the Runge-Kutta integration method. Numerical results reveal some fundamental characteristics of the nonlinear cable vibration.

sec.title: 2. Coupled nonlinear vibration model of inclined cable and bridge deck
sec.p: A three-d.f. nonlinear model for the undamped vibration of the cable/deck coupling system is proposed in this paper. Despite the simplicity of this model, the mechanism and the basic characteristics of the parametric excitation-induced cable vibration can be reflected by numerical solution of the corresponding partial differential equations. The proposed nonlinear vibration model is elaborated in the following text.

At the static equilibrium position, the chord and the vertical plane define the axis Ox and the plane Oxy, respectively (see Figure 1). The in-plane vibration occurs in the Oxy plane and the out-of-plane vibration occurs in direction Oz. Figure 1.
Nonlinear vibration model of an inclined cable.

In the model shown in Figure 1, u, v and w represent the displacements of a point located at (x, y, z) (static equilibrium position) on the cable along the axes Ox, Oy and Oz, respectively; x2 is the displacement of the bridge deck; m1 is the mass of the cable per unit length; E, L and A are the Yong's modulus, the length and the cross-sectional area of the cable, respectively; ϕ is the inclination angle of the cable, m2 and K represent the mass and bending rigidity of the bridge deck, respectively. As usual, the bending stiffness of the cable is neglected.
The governing equations of the cable are (Berlioz and Lamarque, 2005): (1)

Here, s is the curvilinear coordinate, T is the cable tension and T = T0 + T1 + T2, where T0 is the tension of the cable at the static equilibrium position, T1 and T2 are the additional tension forces induced by the movement of the cable and the bridge deck, respectively.
This paper considers the vibration of the bridge deck as an independent d.f., thus T1 and T2 are expressed as (2) (3) where ε1 is axial strain associated with the cable movement.

The motion of the bridge deck m2 is governed by (4) where x¨ 2 denotes the second-order derivative of x2 with respect to time t and xst represents the displacement of the bridge deck at its equilibrium position.

The initial static profile of the cable is assumed to be parabolic and it can be thus expressed by (Irvine, 1981): (5) where H is the static tension along the axis Ox and H≈T0 under the small sag assumption. Thus, neglecting the cable deformation along the axis Ox, equations (1) and (4) can be rewritten as (6) with the boundary conditions v(0, t) = 0 , w(0, t) = 0 , v(L,t)=x2cosϕ and w(L, t) = 0 at both ends of the cable. Obviously, the variation of the cable tension introduces coupling terms into the vibration equations.

Equation (6) can be discretized through Galerkin's method. To this end, we define the trial solutions as (7) (8) where φ1(x) and φ2(x) are the first in-plane and the first out-of-plane cable-dominant modes, respectively, and are defined by (Irvine, 1981) (9) (10)
In equation (9), ω is determined by the following equation (Irvine, 1981): (11) where λ2 is given by (12) with (13)

Inserting equations (2), (3), (7), (8), (9) and (10) into equation (6), yields
(14)
The coefficients in equation (14) are given in Appendix A. The following equation can be obtained from the last equation in equation (14): (15)
By inserting equation (15) into the first equation of equation (14), one obtains (16)
Finally, the coupled equations of the cable and bridge deck are obtained as (17) where (18) (19) (20)

In the above equations, ω1 and ω2 are the in-plane and the out-of-plane natural frequencies of the cable, respectively; ω3 is the natural frequency of the bridge deck. It can be seen from the above expressions that ω1 relies on the initial tension T0, the cable length L, the inclination angle ϕ, the tensile stiffness EA, the mass per unit length of the cable m1 and the mass of the bridge deck m2; ω2 is dependent on the initial tension T0, the cable length L, the inclination angle ϕ and the mass per unit length of the cable m1; ω3 is determined by the tensile stiffness EA, the cable length L and the inclination angle ϕ of the cable together with the mass m2 and the bending stiffness K of the bridge deck. It should be noted that ω1, ω2 and ω3 may not describe the actual free vibration characteristics of the overall nonlinear dynamic system due to the linear/nonlinear coupling effects and the veering phenomenon that occurs between local (cable-dominant) and global (deck-dominant) vibration modes for certain parameter combinations (Gattulli and Lepidi, 2007). However, for a relatively weakly coupled cable/deck system, these frequencies can be used for roughly examining the tuning conditions of parametric resonance between the cable and the deck.

The equations in (17) describe the interactions among the transverse cable oscillation and the bridge deck motion. Though some other cable-deck coupled vibration models have been successfully employed for interpreting large cable oscillations observed in real engineering, this model aims to provide further insight into the complex cable vibration behaviors by simultaneously incorporating both the in-plane and the out-of-plane vibration modes, as well as an independent d.f. for the deck motion.

In an analytical solution approach, a common practice is to discard some higher-order nonlinear terms of equation (17) and to rewrite the equations in principal modal coordinates so that linear coupling terms vanish. In this study, however, equation (17) is directly treated by using a time integration method. This approach has an advantage that some basic characteristics of cable-deck interaction, e.g. the energy transfer between different cable vibration modes (in-plane and out-of-plane) and the beating phenomenon, can be better revealed.

sec.title: 3. Numerical results and discussions
sec.p:
An actual cable studied by Lilien and Pinto da Costa (1994) is considered here and its parameters are presented in Table 1. Table 1.
Parameters of the cable
A(m2) T0(N) L(m) m1(kg/m) ϕ E (Pa)
1.53 × 10−2 8 × 106 50 133 π/3 1.9 × 1011

The fourth-order Runge-Kutta integration method is employed for solving the nonlinear equations in (19). In order to study the effect of the frequency ratio of ω1, ω2 and ω3 on the vibration amplitude of the cable, the natural frequency ratio is changed by adjusting the value of the mass m2 and bending stiffness K of the bridge deck. The numerical solutions for V(t), W(t)) and x2 (t) under various parameter combinations and initial conditions are summarized in what follows.

Obviously, the frequency ratio is far away from the range of parametric resonance. Under initial conditions V(0)=0.0001m,W(0)=0.0001m and x2(0)=0.1m, the obtained time-history response of V, W and x2, as well as their Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) results are shown in Figures 2, 3 and 4, respectively. Figure 2.
Solution of V when ω1:ω2:ω3=1:1.0704:2.6458: (a) time-history; (b) amplitude of Fast Fourier Transform. Figure 3.
Solution of W when ω1:ω2:ω3=1:1.0704:2.6458: (a) time-history; (b) amplitude of Fast Fourier Transform. Figure 4.
Solution of x2 when ω1:ω2:ω3=1:1.0704:2.6458: (a) time-history; (b) amplitude of Fast Fourier Transform.

It can be observed from the time-history plots that the cable is barely excited by vibration of the bridge deck and little energy shifts between the in-plane motion and the out-of-plane motion. Two major frequencies can be identified from the Fourier amplitude density shown in Figure 2(b), with one being the natural frequency of the cable and another the natural frequency of the deck.

As mentioned above, the parametrical resonation may occur under certain ratios between the natural frequencies of the cable and the bridge deck. Therefore, two other frequency ratios ω1:ω2:ω3=1:1.0704:2 and ω1:ω2:ω3=1:1:2 are considered in the following.

In this case, the initial conditions V(0)=0.0001m,W(0)=0 and x2(0)=0.1m are first considered. The time histories and the FFT of V and x2 are plotted in Figures 5 and 6. The results reveal that the parametric resonance of the cable/deck system is excited but there is no out-of-plane response (W = 0). This indicates the occurrence of the parametric resonance phenomenon between the in-plane cable vibration and the support movements, as documented in some physical experimental studies (see e.g. Benedettini and Rega, 1997). Figure 5.
Solution of V when ω1:ω2:ω3=1:1.0704:2,W(0)=0: (a) time-history; (b) amplitude of Fast Fourier Transform. Figure 6.
Solution of x2 when ω1:ω2:ω3=1:1.0704:2,W(0)=0: (a) time-history; (b) amplitude of Fast Fourier Transform.

It can be seen from Figure 5 that the amplitude of the in-plane vibration of the cable immediately reaches its peak value, which greatly exceeds the initial perturbation value, while the vibration amplitude of the bridge deck has little change compared with its initial value. An obvious beating phenomenon can also be observed. That is to say, the oscillation amplitudes of the cable and the bridge deck vary periodically with respect to time, and one attains its maximum while the other reaches its minimum. However, it has been identified that the total energy is constant over the course of vibration, which reflects the conservative nature of the system. Moreover, it can also be seen from Figure 5 that the cable vibration is not symmetric because of the sag.

We then consider the initial conditions V(0)=0.0001m,W(0)=0.0001m and x2(0)=0.1m under the same frequency ratio. The displacement responses V, W and x2 are presented in Figures 7, 8 and 9. Figure 7.
Solution of V when ω1:ω2:ω3=1:1.0704:2,W(0)=0.0001m: (a) time-history; (b) amplitude of Fast Fourier Transform. Figure 8.
Solution of W when ω1:ω2:ω3=1:1.0704:2,W(0)=0.0001m: (a) time-history; (b) amplitude of Fast Fourier Transform. Figure 9.
Solution of x2 when ω1:ω2:ω3=1:1.0704:2,W(0)=0.0001m: (a) time-history; (b) amplitude of Fast Fourier Transform.

Compared with Figures 5 and 6, the maximum amplitude of V and x2 and the frequency of the beat are almost the same. In addition, the amplitude of the out-of-plane vibration is relatively small, which indicates that large amplitude out-of-plane vibration does not occur under this frequency ratio. Further numerical simulations show that the initial perturbation of the cable has little effect on the maximum amplitude of the cable and the maximum amplitude of the cable is actually dependent upon the initial perturbation of the bridge deck.

For the case of the frequency ratio ω1:ω2=1:1, it can be expected that the large amplitude out-of-plane oscillation called swing may occur and this has also been confirmed by the numerical integration results as presented in the following. The frequency ratio of ω1:ω3=1:2 also meets the condition of parametric resonance between the cable and the deck.

Firstly, we consider the initial perturbation V(0)=0.0001m, W(0) = 0 and x2(0)=0.1m. The numerical results for the response V and x2 are shown in Figure 10 and Figure 11, respectively. In this case, the out-of-plane response is not excited. Figure 10.
Solution of V when ω1:ω2:ω3=1:1:2,W(0)=0: (a) time-history; (b) amplitude of Fast Fourier Transform. Figure 11.
Solution of x2 when ω1:ω2:ω3=1:1:2,W(0)=0: (a) time-history; (b) amplitude of Fast Fourier Transform.

The same characteristics, such as the beating phenomenon and unsymmetrical vibration of the cable, are reflected by the predicted time-history responses shown in Figures 10 and 11. However, the frequency of the beat becomes greater, which means that the speed of energy transfers becomes slower. At the same time, the amplitude of V also becomes greater, which implies that more energy is transferred to the vibration of the cable.

Under the same frequency ratio and another set of initial perturbations V(0) = 0.0001 m, W(0) = 0.0001 m and x2(0)=0.1m, the time-history response of V, W, x2 and their FFT results are obtained as shown in Figures 12, 13 and 14. It can be seen that a large-amplitude out-of-plane vibration is excited and the energy transfers among the in-plane cable vibration, the out-of-plane cable vibration and the bridge deck vibration. When the out-of-plane vibration is not excited (in the first three seconds), the results shown in Figure 12 are almost the same as those shown in Figure 10; yet when the out-of-plane vibration is fully excited, the amplitude of in-plane oscillation decreases, which suggests that more energy transfers to the out-of-plane vibration. Figure 12.
Solution of V when ω1:ω2:ω3=1:1:2,W(0)=0.0001m: (a) time-history; (b) amplitude of Fast Fourier Transform. Figure 13.
Solution of W when ω1:ω2:ω3=1:1:2,W(0)=0.0001m: (a) time-history; (b) amplitude of Fast Fourier Transform. Figure 14.
Solution of x2 when ω1:ω2:ω3=1:1:2,W(0)=0.0001m: (a) time-history; (b) amplitude of Fast Fourier Transform.

In addition, compared with Figures 7, 8 and 9, the amplitudes of V and W become greater while that of x2 become smaller. This fact shows that more energy is transferred from the deck vibration to the cable vibration in this case. Further numerical analysis shows that it is the amplitude of the bridge deck that determines the vibration amplitude of the cable while the original perturbations of the cable have only insignificant influence. This implies the importance of deck vibration control for suppressing the cable oscillation in real engineering.

sec.title: 4. Conclusions
sec.p:
In this paper, a nonlinear model for coupled vibration of an inclined cable and the deck in cable-stayed bridges was presented. In this model, the interactions between the in-plane/out-of-plane modes and an independent d.f. describing the bridge deck movement are considered. In conjunction with the Galerkin discretization, a fourth-order Runge Kutta time-integration method was employed to solve the differential equations. By comparing numerical solutions obtained under different frequency ratios and initial conditions, the following conclusions can be drawn:
In the cable-stayed system, if the frequency ratio of the in-plane vibration mode and the vibration of the bridge deck is close to the 1:2 tuning condition, large amplitude vibration of the cable can be excited.
The factors that determine the maximum amplitude of the cable are the frequency ratio of the in-plane vibration to the vibration of the bridge deck and the amplitude of the bridge deck; while the initial perturbations of the cable have no significant influence.
When the frequency ratio of in-plane vibration to the out-of-plane vibration is close to 1:1, large amplitude out-of-plane vibration of the cable can be excited under small out-of-plane perturbations. Moreover, an obvious beating phenomenon can be observed with energy transferring between the cable and the bridge deck.

The present three-d.f. model is not a good idealization of the infinite dimensional cable-deck system. However, it may help to gain further understanding of complex cable-deck interactions and provide some guidance towards future study on suppressing parametric resonance-induced cable vibration.
